The infographic is great, but what really sets this idea apart from other 'copper pipe' concepts is the thought put into complimenting, rather than replacing, hoppers. The configuration scheme builds nicely off wall / pane logic, and the ability to use less hoppers and greatly simplify vertical item transfer would be incredible for performance. Here are some ideas I'd like to add:

  • 'Pulling' items from containers should remain firmly in the domain of hoppers, reinforcing their role as flow control blocks and ensuring most item transfer designs still need at least one hopper. Barrels could be the exception to this, complimenting their compactness.
  • Further extending the principle of copper pipes pushing rather than pulling items, the behavior at junctions should be to merge item flow rather than divide it. Splitting a stream of items would seem to fall into hoppers' domain of flow control, and indeed, very elegant designs for even item distribution have been made using hoppers.
  • Limiting copper pipes to a single output would also greatly simplify linking logic: Each pipe has a single output link at the block face it was placed against, and has input links only where hoppers, droppers, and other pipes have their respective outputs going into it. This would remove the need for a shift-click behavior that would complicate placement against containers, and it would allow for a variety of parallel and converging pipeline networks.

Even more ideas I'd like to add to this, a bit more on the technical side:

Copper pipes could be made even more unique by being coded as technically not even a container–instead, each pipe in a completed network could simply store the ultimate destination of the pipeline and the length of the pipeline from the given block to that endpoint. Thus, internally, the pipes would never really contain items–the game would process the transfer directly from end-to-end, with an added delay proportional to the length of the piping.

This special status as a non-container would allow the pipes to have one more intriguing feature: a redstone comparator reading a copper pipe could give an output proportional to the rate of item flow through it. This would open the door for a whole new spectrum of dynamic systems, such as a super-smelter that saves fuel by running less furnaces in parallel when it is receiving items more slowly.

I am in fact a java player, and so have not experienced the new mountain generation. I like to preserve the new experiences for survival anyway (hope you can respect that). But I still have a few suggestions. I have been backpacking in several mountains before (IRL), and notice some features that Minecraft does not quite model correctly.

First, the mountains of Minecraft look more like skyscrapers than mountains. In fact, the most common mountains, such as the Himalayan Mountain Range, are more like pyramids, and slowly rise, though there are definitely many cliffs.
Inside the mountains there should be Blue Ice

If there were to be unchanged mountains, that would be the Badlands. Just look up Zion National Park and you'll see they are geographically different from the Himalayas in numerous ways. Just make sure to add a snow line and powder snow to the appropriate areas.

I feel that the frequency of mountains is too low and fails to leave a significant impact on the world generation. Personally, I would love to have more mountains to allow the natural beauty of them to shine.

Finding mountains is epic, they are so much bigger than anything we've had before!

I like how they generated in a "range", at least the set I found.

I thought the challenge level for climbing them was well balanced - not hard enough to be frustrating but difficult enough to be engaging. I would have liked more defined peaks - I guess a little less noise in the heightmap. 

With the additional world height, it would make sense to me to raise the "snow" level too. Snow in the hills seems misplaced now.

Edit to add: I found what looked like a standalone Mountain Meadows area. Nothing taller than the old Extreme Hills biome, but the terrain generation was so much nicer (except when it intersected with water). I may never be ok looking at the old Extreme Hills ever again! ;)
Patches of Powder Snow should be more than one block deep much more oftenly, otherwise they wouldn't really be a threat which deincentivises the usage of Leather Boots!

Secondly, the biosphere looks a little wonky. The alpine tundra can just suddenly start when previously you were in a swamp, which is generally known to be at sea level. There are many layers that a mountain comprises in terms of the amount of life, and alpine tundra generally starts at around five or six thousand feet (at least that's what it's like in the Pacific Northwest; Sweden or Tanzania could be different stories). Even in the tundra there are copses and meadows filled with beautiful flowers. But things get maybe a little more baren at seven or eight thousand feet. I have seen traces of mountain goats or the goats themselves hanging around the border between the meadows and the rocky areas. In the summer, there are bus to football field sized snow patches intermittent in those same areas that the goats hang out, however in the winter I assume they are covered in fresh snow. Since (as of yet, riight;) there are no seasons in Minecraft, I assume it is late spring, and the major snow patches can be found in the rocky parts of the mountain. At ten thousand feet, the snow is there to stay, though it may become thicker or thinner. Beyond ten thousand feet, I donno, I have never hiked that far, but I do know that the snow becomes more of a problem/danger what with the snow patches becoming glaciers with concealed and very, very deep crevasses. Anyway, the main idea is that there are many layers from the foothills to the peaks.
But of course the height limit probably won't accommodate for that, so the mountain should be much wider and slowly increase in cliffiness to make them feel remote from the other biomes.

And in my opinion there should be multiple cloud levels, maybe the lower ones would feel more like a fog and occur much less commonplace, while the others look like the fluffy wet things we see everyday, which would flow thirty blocks above the current (320.O) height limit. Also there are clouds that uncommonly occur over mountaintops called lenticular clouds, they look like UFOs and stay in one place for hours. Go look that last one up.
The old generation of tall terrain should be changed, too, right now it's quite simply terrible.
There should be mountains that are encased in other biomes. These mountains would be a sub-biomes of both the biome that it is encased in, and the overall mountain biome.

Mountains are far too rare; I think making extreme hills and mountains spawn half-and-half would be a good idea. Don't worry about putting mountains in the center of extreme hills as that would make traversal annoying and limits the variety in the landscape around the mountains. Just have them spawn separately (as they are now) and increase the spawn rate of mountains considerably. I believe I heard somewhere that the height limit for mountains is ~256. If this is for performance then that's fine, but if it's to allow room for building, then experiment with giving them more height. Perhaps up to 300 or 280. This cuts the building space on the tallest mountains, but not every mountain (presumably) will spawn at the max height and I think this would make mountains even better while giving variety via mountains varying in height (~200 - ~300).
It's tough to identify the biomes without a proper locate command and thus making recommending biome ideas and tweaks extremely difficult as well due to not knowing if the recommendation is already in the game. Having this command added in an upcoming beta would be a great tool for users who want to give feedback in the coming months as tweaks are added to the mountain biomes.

That said, having a "floating islands" biome would be a really cool addition to this update. They don't have to have a flat surface or anything, they can just be large chunks of floating rock of various shapes. Giving iron increased spawn rates here (higher than current mountains) presents some mining strategy as well as lore/world-building implications.

 

Back to the current mountains: the powdered snow should be able to spawn up to 2 or 3 blocks deep. One block makes it easier to traverse, but given that it can be avoided with leather boots defeats the purpose of having powdered snow one block deep. They're already easy enough to traverse if resources are expended a little. Also having areas that can snow (snow biomes and near the height limit) should give freezing damage, but much slower/less than powdered snow. As it is now, leather boots allows you to avoid both slowness and freezing damage since the respective effects only happen when you're inside powdered snow. Leather chest piece is useless for avoiding damage. Either have cold biomes give freezing damage or have powdered snow give freezing damage if you're standing on top of it with boots (without the slowness). This prevents the workaround for the mechanics from being consolidated into one item which makes it too easy.

The new mountains are off to a great start! They're not too difficult to navigate but offer great views and interesting terrain. But there are a few things that could be tweaked/improved to really make them shine.

First off, grass slopes look a bit barren with the lack of grass or plants or anything to add texture. This is a problem with other biomes in Bedrock too, namely plains and savanna, where double tall grass is more common than normal tall grass which results in very flat looking environments. Increasing the spawn rate of tall grass would definitely help break up the monotony of some mountain slopes.

Second, with the new world height, existing mountain biomes should be raised to be equivalent of their java counterparts. Extreme hills, savanna m, etc. Currently on Bedrock, they're cut off at y=128 (cloud height) which looks a bit odd next to the new mountains.

Last thing, there's an odd little graphical glitch where top snow and snowy grass render with mismatched lighting: https://bugs.mojang.com/browse/MCPE-57022. Maybe caused by similar circumstances as slabs, stairs, walls, etc. being lit inconsistently with their full block counterparts (https://bugs.mojang.com/browse/MCPE-54410). It's such a small visual blemish but it makes a big difference when exploring the new snowy mountains.

Those are some bits of feedback I thought of while playing the beta. The new features are great so far, and this update is shaping up to be one of Minecraft's greatest! Keep it up, Mojang :)

Seeing the top of a high mountain from a plain or a deep hole in the ground is pretty insane so I suggest to add a new state into the game which is in 4 tiers: crystal, very foggy, quite foggy and foggy days.

They would have no impact on gameplay below Y 128 but work this way:

if the day is in one of the 3 foggy tiers you cannot see structures higher up than 128 no matter the render distance, so you see the base of the mountain but need to climb to its top:

  • if the day is foggy after passing Y 128 at an example height of 200 you can only see 45 blocks up and 45 blocks down your Y position (so 245 and 155)
  • if the day is quite foggy at the same example height you can see only 35 blocks up and 35 down
  • if the day is very foggy you can only see 25 blocks up and 25 blocks down
  • in crystal clear days you can see up and down as of now limited by your render distance only

At around 128 this would work a little bit differently:

  • if the day is in a foggy tier after going from 128 to 129 you do not instantly loose sight of dowards ground:you will loose sight of the Y areas below 128 gradually and the complete lost of contact will happen at Y 153 (128 plus 25) no matter the fog day tier. The upwards sight level just above 128 will slowly transition to the correct level of sight depending on the fog tier instead

The mountains look great in the new beta but I feel like the update hasn’t been integrated into the rest of the game unlike the caves. The caves have been completely overhauled, & there were great changes throughout that affected the entire underground, but all the existing mountain types such the M type of certain biomes like the desert or jungle, or the plateaus of the badlands haven’t been touched. The updated mountains themselves are amazing, of course, but I feel that the existing mountain biomes of times past should also be updated. Speaking of mountains & existing features, I feel that the existing water features like rivers & lakes should be expanded upon to again, be more integrated. Things like river valleys, glaciers, lakes, water falls cascading down the sides & even oceans with imposing cliff side overhangs would provide an inspiring experience for travellers to delve into. Delving into caves unique to the mountains would also be an experience to behold & a good way of integrating the caves part of the update into the cliffs. In conclusion, I do feel that the current mountains are great, they are in fact wonderful, it just feels like they have been popped into one area, leaving the rest of the mountain generation in other biomes & surrounding features to feel outdated.

The new mountains look amazing but there's still some things that need to get flushed out:

1. The snow/grass border around the mountains looks unnatural. It should look more jagged and have more variation.

2. The new mountain biomes are extremely rare and should definitely be bumped up in terms of how frequently they spawn. They should also spawn in ranges and not the typical biome 'blobs'.

3. The old mountains should have some changes made to them to make sure that they don't stick out. Right now they're ugly and barren and need some basic changes such as smoother/steeper terrain and a better foilage color, as well as some extra plants and trees.

4. The clouds should be modified to spawn in multiple layers, and they should come with more variation to thickness and texture, as well as opacity. This would help with the atmosphere in the new mountain biomes, or heck it could just give the overworld a much nicer feel to it.

I think the new mountains are great. I like how they are steep and dominating, but it would be nice to also have ones generating with more gradual slopes, but which would still lead up to the colossal heights of these new peaks. This could be done by making the terrain height independent of biome, and instead give each block a value for a continuous 'depth' parameter, which would control the average height of terrain. Also, a local water level could be tied to the depth parameter and be used to generate mountain-level lakes and rivers.

Another suggestion would be to have some variation in certain decorations. For example, tree density could vary and could thin out smoothly as a transition between a forested biome and non-forested biome.

It would also be great if mountainous terrain (cliffs and overhangs) were a proper part of other biomes in the game too, rather than just the mountain/hill types. 

Finally, perhaps the grass and foliage colours of the new mountain biomes could be made a little more vibrant - currently, if the player wishes to build in a mountain biome, they are restricted only to dull, blueish grass.

As they have added bundles, rabbit hide has become valuable. Rabbits should spawn way more frequently in the new mountains (perhaps at a significant height) to motivate players who might not seek anything else the heights have to offer.

I am worried about this new update. It gives Minecraft a great touch of randomness, chaos, and un-predictable-ness, that me and a number of people really like. I am worried that this new update will remove those features forever. A possible solution could be, if its not too much to ask, is that you add a mountain biome or sub-biome (like the ones you just announced) that still generates mountains in the old chaotic manner like it used to. It would really be appreciated by Minecraft veterans who remember playing with those older CRAZIER cliffs.

To preface this, I really like the new mountains, they are a great improvement to Minecraft. However, here are a few ideas that I think would improve upon what was added in beta.

 1. Make the mountains into larger mountain ranges that span across thousands of blocks. 

     a. There can still be lone peaks but make them look more like lone peaks (reference mountains such as Mt. Shasta, etc.) 

2.Add multiple biomes on the mountain relating to elevation, such as alpine and add new trees. Trees should also get sparser and smaller as elevation increases.

    a. Add animals like marmots/pikas to alpine biome?

In addition to that, It would be cool to add a new biome called "foothills" and basically foothills will always generate right below mountains. You could have variants of foothills, for example "forested foothills" etc to create more variation. 

Below the foothills you could add another biome called like "sagebrush flatlands". Past the sagebrush flatlands you could have deserts, savannas, mesas, etc. So to quickly recap, there'd be a continuum of biomes that will generate, from green/colder biomes to drier biomes as it gets further from the mountains. 

Mountains can also be made more colorful by adding flowers to the slopes of the mountains. Meadows would also be a good addition. 

Finally, another cool addition would also be creeks, streams, and waterfalls that flow from the mountains and join into a river flowing away from the mountains and carrying it into larger lakes or oceans.

The new mountains look stunning so far! One small problem I've noticed with the generation is that there are sometimes these weird 90 degree corners at the bases, but aside from that, the generation is excellent.

In terms of content though, there could be more. In a recent video on Minecraft's YouTube channel, it was stated that the team tries to balance out the "journey" and "reward" features. While the mountains themselves serve as both excellent journey and reward features, they honestly don't serve much of a purpose for those who are not interested in building on or near them. This could be fixed by adding some unique blocks or items, or even a structure. The goat may end up serving an interesting purpose, but I don't think it's quite enough. There needs to be a good reason to keep returning to the mountains.

Finally, I think the mountains don't generate as frequently as they should. As great as they look so far, they once again don't offer up much in terms of rewards and aren't worth spending long periods of time searching for if you don't want to live near them. They serve as excellent backgrounds/backdrops though, and I think it would be a waste to not take advantage of that by making them generate somewhat more frequently.

Due to varying performance, varying world heights are needed. With 1.17 coming mountains are being heightened, while caves are being deepened. Because mountains themselves vary, we can adjust the world height accordingly. For example, if in world generation a mountain that would stand a glorious 204 blocks tall was generated, it would be an exemption to the world height, while any of the player's builds would be restricted from being built if a significant distances outward from that mountain. If a cave generated below a wonder of –48, bedrock would generate so that it would rap around that cave like a wall. This could be cool, as it would make a pit that the player could not mine out of but only pillar.                                                                                                                                              If one knew their computer was capable of processing so much information, they could decrease the slope by which the build limit would also be decreased.

I love the new Mountains, Ive seen some spectacular ones in the Beta so far. There are many secrets that have yet to be revealed and Ive seen some interesting ones, like frozen aquifers with liquid tunnels of water webbing the bottom of the ice. If I had to suggest something about their look, I would say the middle of a mountain should be thicker and pointier. The mountains should be pointier in general. Bigger, taller, thicker spires of stone, and more sheer cliffs and steep slopes. Think the Matterhorn, or the Grand Tetons. A lot of them are like lots of similarly sized stone nubs and bumps sticking out of a cratered Mt. Ranier. Were looking for essentially a main pyramid like mound of jagged stone surrounded by smaller pyramids, all of varying degrees of angles (stout, to tall thin and pointy) I would also love to see more sheer cliffs that face the ocean instead of sloping down to it. I would like to see a unique flower or plant that can only be found in the higest parts of the mountains. The introduction of a new biome should always have a native flora and fauna. We have the goats, a beautiful flower would be the cherry on top. This is the perfect time to add a low growing bushy Lavender, which grows in alpine conditions. The Avalanche Lily is a beautiful star shaped white flower with a yellow center and grows in alpine meadows, its incredible. Alternatively, a new fantasy plant, an Ice Flower of sorts. You could use it in a recipe for avoiding freezing damage, or just because it would look nice. It would be great in the alpine meadows in the Mountains, and can be brought to other snowy biomes for terraforming. A bushy Lavender plant would also look amazing in a desert, to simulate desert bloom. They should kind of feather together so they look like theyre sprawling. I could go on lol. You get the idea. As an aside, seeing short stubby spruce trees, stunted in growth, like the nubby jungle trees that are two high, would look better on the sides of the mountains.

Calcite is too beautiful to limit it to the rare geodes! Having it be in the mountains would give servers enough of the material for any player to use for building and make the new biome even more coveted than theyll already be. I realize there will be Emerald Ores, but theyre not as useful for builds as calcite is, and they can be found a lot more easily than a geode.

Moulins: essentially a crevasse, but its deep and one block wide. In essence, a crack carver, but maybe shorter, lenth and depth wise. The mouth of it would be concealed by powdered snow. This is how they are in real life. The sides would be packed ice, or blue ice, or a gradient of the two, and the bottom would have a random depth of water, or powdered snow. Falling in wouldnt be fatal itself, but you would be trapped until you dug your way back up, or ended in a cave by some chance of generation, or you froze. This would actually be a great feature for snowy tundra tbh. Its not overly punitive to players as you still have a chance to get out, and if youre wearing leather boots and gear you will be fine. This is good emergent gameplay.

Here are a few characteristics of mountains that may give the mountains more grandeur.

–Mountains are huge, but that doesn't mean they constitute a whole biome, such as a forest.

–Mountains are a complex of ridges and valleys, cliffs and plateaus, glaciers and waterfalls, copses and rocky tundra (they even have their own weather, but I won't go there). They aren't a complex of blobs.

–Thunder is being stolen from mountains, the culprits: trees and hills; the plains don't even look flat. In fact, they look like a scaled down mountain biome. Being in a superflat world is the most Prairie-like Minecraft experience that can be had. Trees on the other hand, can reach the top of a major cliff easily. This could be solved by making a typical, non-mountain hill seven blocks tall. As for trees, make the cliffs twenty times taller than the trees. If there was a tree that was seven blocks tall, the cliff would be 140 blocks tall.

Ok so from my experience playing I have 2 main issues:

Generation isn’t as smooth as it could be; Biomes frequently stretch a 1000 blocks

I find that the flat areas should be smoother and lower lying as they don’t really serve their function of being good building areas. Too often a river will flow through creating a ditch, and you get a similar effect with beaches. Which is particularly annoying if you want a beachside build because gradual transitions are best for that.  
However I do enjoy the cliff effect that stony shore’s give when transitioning higher elevations into the ocean. 
Large Caves also intersect the surface too frequently. Though it can be beautiful when you find one it seems to happen quite frequently, producing pit falls and tearing up the terrain.  Personally I think small cave entrances at the surface and larger caves generally being deeper would be for the best because you then have a difficulty gradient as the deeper you go there are more big caves which have more dark spaces. 
Then some Biomes are just too big, especially with the rougher terrain travelling is slower and so crossing a 700 by 700 plains to find something new is arduous.

The Glow Ink Sack could be used to make Glowing Dyes, wich would function just like regular Dyes, but mixed with the Glow Ink Sack Features.

What i mean is that Glow Dyes would paint concrete/ leather/ banners/ wool/ etc just like usual, but these blocks would not be affected by light level, so they would always be bright, in the dark.

But, just like the glowing effect on glow squids, they would not emit light, so they wouldn't be light sources, thus keeping it vanilla-friendly by not adding moving light sources.

This mechanic would be so cool!

  • Builders could now have blocks that are not affected by light level, so now imagine the possibilites of color gradients!
  • Map makers would now have the ability to make cool new puzzles, like, for example, a secret path that is only visible (highlighted) when dark, or something like this.
  • Both leather armor and banners would be way more cool to desing, as you could now have parts that glow in the dark! Not emiting light, again, but still cool nevertheless!
  • Mob farms would be even more nice, becaus now you could mix the tinted glass and the highlithed concrete blocks to make funcional mob farms (as it would still technically be dark enough for them to spawn) but visible at the same time!

1.part
I have several ideas for Glow Squids in Minecraft.
1)Glowing Lakes
Because of the glow and sparkles of Glow Squids, I don't think they belong to the regular aquafires filled with water. Instead, I think they could spawn in a new biome called the Glow Lakes! Those would be aquafires with some kind of new glowing blocks and plants and ofc Glow Squids. The new glowing block would be found on the ground and walls of the aquafier and could be used in decorative purposes. It would glow and have a blue/green colour just like Glow Squids. So it would be a brand new glowing block with a unique colour which would especially be used in the caves, in the dark and of course under the water. For the glowing plants, I think we could have something like glowing seagrass or kelp, or maybe something different, I don't really know. But it would be shiny and glowy and magical, and would be used to breed Glow Squids, which is my second idea!
2) Baby Glow Squids
Baby Glow Squids! They would be really adorable and would really fulfill the Glow Lakes! Also, the cool thing is that you could pick it up in a bucket and take them anywhere you want. That way we could transport Glow Squids and take them to our own aquafires, gardens, lakes and make a cool atmosphere anywhere we want! They wouldn't drop anything just like other baby animals, but they would ofc grow into a big, standard Glow Squids.

2.part
3) Glowing Dye
The uses for Glow Ink Sacks are cool, but I don't think people use it that much. So, we could have a brand new tipe of dye! It would have a blue/green colour just like Glow Squids and would naturally glow! It could be used to make Glowing Leather Armour, which many people already want. But I think that we could use both Glow Ink Sacks and Glowing Dyes to dye a leather armour. Glowing Dyes would be used as every other dye, with its own colour + have the glowing effect, and Glow Ink Sacks would just make armour glow, no mather the colour it has. It would only serve for decorative purposes, but it would give both Glow Squids and leather armour a big and cool usage. We could also have Glowing Leather Horse Armour, so we could see our horses in the dark! In any case, it would be really cool and we could have a brand new sort of dye with its own colour and a unique feature, glowing!
4) New Light Blocks
My last idea is not so related to the Glow Squid, but could be used with a Glowing Dye that i mentioned. I think we should have some kind of coloured light blocks. They would just have so many uses in decoration and could easily change the game for the better. They could be crafted using 4 Glass blocks, 4 Amethyst Shards and a dye in the middle of the Crafting Table. This could also Make a new usage for Amethyst! It would have a similar texture like Tinted Glass and would emite a light level of 16. I think it would especially be cool with a new Glowing Dye!

Feedback on glow ink sac:

You can combine glow ink sac with any dye to make a glow dye (eg. glow ink sac + red dye = red glow dye).  You can put the glow dye in cauldrons or on banners. 

The dye on banners would give a similar effect as glow item frames, but only on the layer that the specific dye is on.  You can then make glowing leather armor using the glow dye.  (P.S. remove the five layer limit on banners as well)

This thread mentions 3 main desired concepts to be added to the lightning rod:
1. Weathered and waxed variants
2. Decorative variants (does not attract lightning; with or without ball on top)
3. Visual connection between lightning rods and other blocks (mainly chains and lanterns)

This comment aims to show how these may work in conjunction, as a personal view on how they could be implemented.

1. Weathered variants
Let's say there are 4 variants and each of them can be waxed. This will multiply any of the further added blocks by 8, so keep in mind we might not want all of them, as not to add 64 different blocks that are all just lightning-rods ;)

2. Decorative variants
This could be done by adding a non-conductive, non-flamable block of terracotta to your lightning rod! This could be done in the crafting table (adding 8 new block variants) or done via blockstate by clicking on it (without shifting) with a terracotta block. In this case, breaking the deactivated lightning rod may not give you back the terracotta (due to implementation limitations), but right clicking it will give it back (reverting the lightning rod back to normal).
The texture of this variant lightning rod could be slightly different (ex. adding a nob below it), but shouldn't be too noticeable.

3. Connection variants
One variant that I think would actually be really nice is just the regular copper rod (lightning rod without ball). This one adds 8 new blocks if you include all weathered and waxed variants.

I also think that maybe they should weather down a level every ten or so times they get struck. After all, they are made of copper, and they should act like how copper does. Still, I think they should only get weathered by the lightning. And like copper blocks, waxing them should stop the weathering.

My final suggestion, maybe make the signal strength given change randomly. After all in real life lightning is unpredictable, and some strikes are more powerful than others. Going on with my prior idea, maybe how much they're weathered would depend on how much power goes into the strike.

When lightning strikes a block that is within range of multiple eligible ("buzzing") lightning rods, the ones at lower Y coordinates seem to be struck instead of the ones higher up (maybe because they are closest to the original strike location?). Wouldn't it be better if the rods higher up were struck instead?

I.e. If lightning was originally going to strike at coordinates X_1, Y_1, Z_1, and multiple lightning rods are horizontally within 64 blocks and are "buzzing", the lightning rod among them that is closest to X_1, Y_h, Z_1 should be struck, where Y_h is the build height. 

Motivation:

I think this would be more realistic because lightning takes the path of least resistance in real life, which translates usually to the highest lightning rods in an area. The lightning comes from the sky after all. I think real world architecture also reflects this behavior and builders' expectations would be that way too.

This exactly what I was thinking; it's almost like there is a giant community of players. However, I do have a few different images as to the crafting, and a few specifications that I would like to emphasize.

Crafting

Looking up photos, I noticed that the seat seemed to be made by tying leather to a frame, and I thought that scaffolds looked like that. However, bamboo isn't the easiest to find, so I suppose it could also be an item frame, however, the scaffolding would offer better warmth, concealment, and protection. You would use waxed lightning rods, or waxed crushed bamboo which is a flattened board of bamboo obtained by feeding a panda a cocoa bean-filled bamboo stick, and taking it from its very glad mouth. Bamboo sticks would be lighter and would make it easier on your dogs' end. They are waxed so that they repel water, reducing capillary drag, helping the sleigh to slide better. However the wax will wear off and your sleigh will not slide as easily so you must wax the runner rails again with honeycomb.

                tripwire hook   blank/item frame   stick

                      fence post   blank/scaff    fence post

        waxed lightning rod   waxed lightning rod   waxed copper ingot*

              /crushed bamboo   /crushed bamboo   bamboo*

*for standing on

There are many factors that must come together to get the sled to make a smooth entrance into Minecraft. One idea I had was to make powder snow flow, though tens of times slower than lava and unable to move entities in its range (unless perhaps the player causes it to become avalanche powder snow by walking on highly sloped deep patches of it without snow shoes, in which case it would flow ten times faster and eight times farther than water and cause sloped powder snow below it and three blocks outward to become avalanche powder snow as well, by a ten percent piece of bad luck), it would take the shape of sloped water. Additionally, the source block of the powder snow has gravity. Doing this would smoothen the mountain slopes, and allow for a smoother sleigh ride.
Sleds should travel much faster when on powder snow.

With this sleigh, you can ride in the seat near the front, or standing on the back. However, if you want to use your wolves, you must ride in the back, standing on the runner rails, so you can see the terrain in front of your pups.

If you want to haul items on this sleigh, you may tie four bundles on the sides of the sleigh near the back, or you can set seven down in the seat towards the front. However, to haul more items, you need to stand on the back.

Hi, I've got a few ideas for the goats. Please do take note that some of these ideas may coincidentally or not be mentioned before. Here are my suggestions:

  • Textures

A passive domestic variant. In order to achieve these, the player needs to bring a mountain goat outside of its natural habitat to be domesticated. It would add to the adventures of the player. Also a rare type whose skin is black. Its spawn rates are similar to those of the brown pandas and pink sheep. It's behavior would be the same to the mountain goat.

  • AI

Domestic goats should be passive and playful. I think they should bleat or scream when they want to taunt or scare you. It would be funny. The complete opposite for the mountain goats who are moody and neutral. Goats would be afraid of water and may eat an item dropped on the floor to emphasize the common notion of goats in both real life and fiction universe.

  • Item Drop

Goat wool called Cashmere. Cashmere has a thicker, rougher, and more durable texture than the sheep wool. It would come in 16 colors, but it would still be flammable; only lasting seconds longer when burned alongside wool. For a food source; goats should drop Goat milk. Unlike cow's milk they give a regeneration or saturation effect. They should also drop their own respective meat called Chevon to add more types of food items in the game.

Goats need to be much more aggressive than they are right now, as they mostly just wander about aimlessly most of the time. To fix this, I think they should try to ram the player about every 12 seconds. To balance this, goats would have a trust stat that goes up if they successfully ram a player, but goes down if the goat took damage from a player. The higher the trust, the more time between rams. Trust is also passed down when breeding.

My reasoning for making goats a lot more threatening is that mountain climbing doesn't feel very rewarding, so having actual threats to avoid would greatly increase the skill factor towards climbing them and make the journey upwards more exciting and thrilling. This is especially the case considering that mountains are very rare, thus the player is usually well prepared when they do find one. The trust mechanic is there mainly so that players could have an easier time making a goat farm, or just having a pet goat around.

Just as Minecraft removed the ability to feed cookies to parrots for animal cruelty concerns, I think the method of obtaining the horn should be changed to not reflect mutilation.
